ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Recommended for Ancient Phil. specialists and non-specialists alike, especially for those interested in philosophy of mind, philosophy of psychology, or ethics who want to learn more about some interesting perspectives that differ in important ways from modern ones but are nevertheless relevant to modern debates and don't seem anachronistic.Due to the methodology of the class, not recommended for those with no interest whatsoever in history of philosophy for its own sake (but those people have an impoverished view of philosophy and should branch out!)

It was a course on Aristotle's and the Stoic's theories of emotion, which is a fascinating topic. If you decide to take it, though, you should definitely expect it to be more concerned with the accompanying metaphysics and nuances of the philosophical theories than with pursuing questions about how such theories of emotion might relate to our own contemporary understanding.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: It deepened my knowledge, as I knew relatively little about these issues before.
